180 A trove of hereditary fortune fading, caught in the gnarled dominion of pride, vengeance, and fate. 340  "The Godfather," directed by Francis Ford Coppola, is not just a film but a cultural phenomenon that has profoundly shaped the landscape of cinema. The 1972 epic, based on Mario Puzo's novel of the same name, paints a powerful portrait of the Corleone family and its entanglement in the world of organized crime. The cinematic brilliance extends across multiple layers, from the stellar acting to the profound narrative, from the impressive visual design to the memorable music.The performances in‚Ä¶

393 Did you know that George Lucas helped Francis Ford Coppola shoot and finish The Godfather? He actually shot a few things, like the newspaper shots. 449 An operatic legend of Italian passion becomes a quintessential piece of American mythology. Nearly every scene of this film has the Corleones wearing masks; masks for loved ones, masks for enemies, even masks for themselves. The perpetual disguise the Corleones put on for the world makes sense when confronted with the terrible truth of their lives. The only truth, the only reality in Michael's fragile existence as the heir to his father's kingdom of decadence, is violence. Well, violence and delicious food.

711  Francis Ford Coppola‚Äôs sprawling crime saga is the definitive movie about taking over the family business because it elegantly builds off of nearly-universal truths about both family and business from a hyper-masculinized perspective. It fixates on the anxiety of unavoidably becoming your own father, the fear of letting down your family by forging your own path, the transformatively healing effect of reconnecting with your roots, and the cutthroat selfishness necessary to maintain power.¬†And by repeatedly insisting on the distinction between‚Ä¶  
712  Something that always stuck out to me about this film is how it uses children throughout the course of its narrative. At different points, years fly by within the matter of minutes and the child characters (who are mostly reserved for the background) are used to confirm the film's time jumps and temporal ellipses. The film begins on the day of Connie Corleone-Rizzi's wedding, or in other words, traditionally speaking, the day a child becomes a woman as she is‚Ä¶  
713 This review may contain spoilers. I can handle the truth.   "Is it true?""No."Organized crime unfurls into an unorganized, rampant, violent mess, only to be cleaned up, baptized with blood by the innocent, now guilty. The tragedy at the heart of The Godfather really doesn't strike until that final, masterful shot. It's a deeply elegiac, utterly devastating moment that tends to get glanced over by those too willing to label the film as a glorification of crime. 1014  78/100(was a 64/100)The great American tragedy. This is not a film of villains and heroes, nor is it a film of moral ambiguity or grayness; instead, it is a film of hollowness--a tragedy of seismic proportions wherein every single character is unable to live a fulfilling life. What Coppola does here, that I hadn‚Äôt understood before, is that he presents us with a world of pain and suffering where nothing gets better and there is only death--that world being‚Ä¶

1479 Considered one of the greatest films ever made and for good reason, Francis Ford Coppola's The Godfather is the textbook definition of a masterpiece, with Coppola and author Mario Puzo crafting a gripping mafia and family story that's deeply powerful and beautifully complex all the same, not to mention full of magnificent performances, nerve-wracking tension, phenomenal dialogue, gorgeous cinematography, and memorable characters. 
1480  "I believe in America." 1522  Very few filmmakers are able to construct a mood the way Coppola does in The Godfather. The use of dark oaky colors throughout establishes the world of the Corleone family as one of concealment and secrecy while the melancholy soundtrack coats the film in a layer introspective sadness and regret. At times it can almost feel as if the score is calling out "things would have been better had you listened to the Godfather". Lighting is used to great effect,‚Ä¶

1527  It seems that the first question everyone asks about "THE GODFATHER" is concerned with Marlon Brando's interpretation of the title role. 1528  "It's not personal Sonny...it's strictly business."- Michael CorleoneIn 1972 Francis Ford Coppola released what is now regarded as one of, if not, the greatest film(s) of all time. That film is The Godfather. The film is based upon Mario Puzo's novel of the same name. In my opinion the film is superior to the book. 1799  50th-anniversary cinematic re-release!The Godfather captures the intrinsic link between gangsterism, capitalism, and patriarchy. What little "action" there is, is presented as horrific and unglamorous: men get beaten and shot unceremoniously on dingy curbsides, their butchered bodies left lying on the cold, New York City asphalt. Meanwhile, the people orchestrating these murders are disaffected business owners, who navigate through endless meetings through strict rules of polite behavior. In their private lives, they constructed a men's world, where the family nucleus‚Ä¶  
1800 American Cinema‚Äôs monument. Profound Shakespearean tragedy framed against a portrait¬†of power in The United States. Ideas such as murder and revenge are presented alongside family and culture. Rather than tired stereotypes, the American criminal is portrayed as an actual human being. Coppola composes his rich tapestry by utilising a cast that has been unsurpassed still. The studio not wanting either Brando or Pacino was quite the revelation. Thankfully, Coppola understood the material and elevated it even further beyond anyone‚Äôs expectations. Films like The Godfather demonstrate the true power of the cinematic medium. I‚Äôm so glad to have seen this on a cinema screen.

2065  The endurance of the film as a cultural monument is not in question. Corleone is a synonym for Mafia tactics and corruption, frequently used to describe repressive and thieving governments. The infamous scene of finding a horse's head in one's bed is a byword for a threat to one's life, likewise the "Sicilian message" of somebody "sleep[ing] with the fishes" if fish are delivered to friends or relatives wrapped in an item of the deceased's clothing. The cast, led by‚Ä¶

2283  Now where do I beginüò≥ I have been wanting to watch this film for a very long time. 2284 Hard to find a better paced movie that's this long. Intricate rituals and grudges weaved together with moments of sudden violence. There's formality to it all, meeting a Don is akin to meeting the Pope. When there's a hit to be carried out, the seating chart is already arranged. Within the formality, the members themselves are casual. Killing is just another errand. It's this composure amidst death that makes Michael's ascent feel preordained. He's clever and calm when the threat is looming, baptized in the blood he spilt.

2815 Few films are as vital to cinematic history as The Godfather. What an absolute classic. What I find so impressive, beyond the filmmaking itself, is how absolutely perfect this team is. From Coppola, to Brando, to Pacino, to Caan, to Gordon Willis, and beyond, every person attached to this film was absolutely perfect for the project. That doesn't happen often in film, and it's so satisfying to rewatch this knowing all of these masters put their heart and soul into this film.

2822 To describe Francis Ford Coppola's The Godfather, in my humble opinion, is to quote Bernard Herrmann when he spoke of Martin Scorsese's Mean Streets:"He does it like Italian opera."Violence, betrayal, romance; it is all on display in what is easily one of the most incredible crime epics in all of film. Elegantly shot by the great Gordon Willis, scored by that great maestro Nino Rota, and starring a marvelous cast, Coppola translates Mario Puzo's chronicle of the Corleone family to the Silver Screen with great beauty, and great brutality. A true masterpiece if there ever was one.

3012  It‚Äôs easy to assume that a complex plot is a sign of a great film. 3191  ‚ÄúThis is the business we‚Äôve chosen!‚ÄùI continue to marvel at the genius of Coppola's narrative structure: its braiding of sequel with prequel using techniques taken from the Modernist novel and owing more to Joseph Conrad than classic Hollywood screenwriters. 3345  Part I tells a complete story of one man's fall into corruption, but Part II is what transforms it into tragedy. 3477 You can never lose your family.Times are changing.The story of America told through one bloodline. A power bid is pitched as a means of protection and freedom. Things "worked" for a time. But as families grow, attitudes shift, technologies and business evolve, the need for capital trumps all. That "protection" was just greed. That "freedom?" A new prison. Brotherhood matters not when trying to keep afloat and ahead of the storm. The inevitability of capitalism is the complete commodification of bodies, minds, and souls. One look at history will tell you that every empire has an expiration date.

4279 Among the very best-looking movies ever made by an American studio, though it narratively falters slightly compared to the original. While The Godfather was a crime epic with a strict plot, this sequel serves more as a character study of Michael -- one that is dark, disturbing, and poignant. That's part of the reason why I prefer this film to its predecessor (by the slimmest of margins, mind you).It's also a testament to this team, and to Coppola's direction, that this film is never boring despite its mammoth runtime.And god damn, that final shot. 4665 This review may contain spoilers. I can handle the truth.  Empires rise and empires fall. Whereas the rise of the Corleone family may be simple; a killing here, a killing there, the slow demise is complex, with Michael grasping at fragile webs of power, slung between deceit and betrayal. His feeble attempts to legitimise the family, drive them apart, as he shows that not even family is safe from business. The Godfather: Part II is a chess match, and whilst Michael may end up playing the winning moves for a checkmate, it costs him pawns, knights and ultimately his queen.

4783 For whatever reason, I tend to favor the second movie in most trilogies, and without question, that trend now applies to The Godfather Part II (I'm sure Part III is great, but I can't see it topping this).Like all the best sequels, The Godfather Part II fleshes out the history of everything that worked in the original, doubles down on character relationships and development, and takes the story into a much deeper, darker, and in many ways more personal direction. 4849 It's wild how different the mood is for this film's "climax" in comparison to the baptism montage of the first film. One of the most hopeless and despairing voids in the history of American cinema. 
4850 The contrast between a son's haggard attempt at exacting old revenges with his father's rise to power. Both fueled by vengeance, the father uniting his family against a common enemy. The son in a paranoid spiral of revenge, removing the familial protection his father established. The father began alone, the son ends alone. Vito feels like a hero and Michael like a villain. It's not just a corruption of power, but the degradation of the soul that comes with revenge.

5128 A deeply felt echo of despair and sadness lines the hollow walls of this tragic portrait of American greed and capitalism corrupting and destroying a man who could not handle the shoes he stepped into, juxtaposed against the father who built that empire decades earlier, and the fluctuating perspectives of these two men. One rises and one crumbles. An immigrant manipulates the American dream as he comes to power, while his American born son becomes cursed with that burden. Slow, quiet and haunted. Would make a good double feature with The Irishman, if you've got 7 hours to kill.

5216 The most supremely overrated sequel of all time which amplifies the vast faults of its predecessor. Plot is non-existent. 5375 The Godfather Part II is like two trains travelling in opposite directions, successive generations moving backwards and forwards through time until they meet somewhere in the middle around the dramatic flashpoint of the family dinner table. The film that marks the beginning of the Corleone family and the end of it is one of the most exquisitely structured pieces of fiction ever produced; its narrative and thematic arcs intertwining across vast stretches space and time through the macrocosm of history and the microcosm of memory. It is an epic of intimate proportions that fulfils the devastation that its predecessor prophesied.

5416 Expanding the scope into a global conflict and utilizing an ingenious flashback structure, Coppola deepens what was so great about the first film. Through the story of one man growing increasingly distanced from his feelings, it matches its portrait of familial bonds and strife with an incisive look at the increasingly intertwined relationship between capitalism and criminal activity. The dissolves between 1910s Vito and 1950s Michael are so elegantly executed. They suggest, in their slow bleeding through time, the deeply ingrained beliefs that are passed on through generations and uphold entire nations.

5890  Ah, the crime drama genre, probably the most prestigious Hollywood genre, and one of my least beloved.Thankfully, The Godfather is the exception to the rule, because it understands that the ONLY way to make a crime drama truly resonant is to have the main character get gradually sucked into it from the outside. If the character is embroiled in organized crime from the outset (Goodfellas, Scarface) that inevitably puts a wedge between him and the audience.That being said,‚Ä¶

6156 For every moment of genuine inspiration in The Godfather: Part III, there are just as many moments that come off tedious, overwrought, or unintentionally funny. The real dramatic heft of the previous two Godfather films is totally absent here, with this third entry feeling like an unnecessary epilogue to the series rather than trying to work as a successful standalone film. Al Pacino gives his all and the movie is handsomely crafted, but as this disappointing finale shows, Francis Ford Coppola was made an offer that he really should have refused.

7239 Lacks the raw power and consistency of previous entries, a problem exacerbated by some poor casting choices. 7605 Apparently Coppola originally wanted to title this The Death of Michael Corleone. 7617  Firstly let me get a rant out of the way, what is the big deal about Sofia Coppola's performance? 8103  It's not bad, exactly, but it suffers in comparison to THE GODFATHER I & II, which are as great as they come. 8288  FRBR (Functional Requirements for Bibliographic Records) is a conceptual model used in librarianship to define what a book is. It distinguishes between the work at the highest conceptual level (e.g. Herman Melville's idea of Moby Dick) through the expression and the manifestation to the item at the base physical level (e.g. a specific paperback copy of Moby Dick). 8872 This is a capsule about The Godfather Coda: The Death of Michael CorleoneWouldn't exactly classify this as a corrective to the original cut, but it definitely smooths some of the rougher edges. Particularly the Vincent/Mary relationship, which has been rightfully criticized vehemently over the years. Mary is still an underwritten role, but she's more posited here as the result of Michael's failures rather than his ignorance. Plus, the film becomes less about class and financial ascension and more about irredeemable moral rot. Fun!
